texts.shortText: Very elongated with many whorls (hence the common name screw-shell). The whorls are flat-sided, such that the shell forms a smoothly-tapering cylinder coming to a sharp point. Aperture small, operculum horny and with concentric rings. Colour white with a distinctive wide, brown band running up the centre of each whorl.
Large, reaching up to 120 mm in length.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast to about East London.

A large and attractive species found buried in sediments in somewhat deeper waters, where it can reach great densities. Particularly common on the Agulhas Bank, where sometimes a dominant part of benthic biomass. Like other screw shells probably lives completely buried head-down into the sediment. Two channels through the sand communicate with the surface and water is drawn down one of these to the gills, which filter out fine particles and transport these in a string of mucus to the mouth, where the mucus string is raked in by the delicate radula. Wastewater is then expelled up the other channel back to the surface.
Filter feeder, filtering water though the gills and transporting captured particles to the mouth along with a string of mucus.

In this family sexes are separate and fertilisation is internal. Females generally lay clusters of egg capsules attached to small stones, each capsule containing 6-20 eggs. These usually hatch within one week and develop as pelagic larvae, although in some species eggs only emerge as crawling larvae. Details of reproductive mode are not known for local species.

One of several screw-shells on the region, which can be distinguished by habitat, as well as shell structure. The Waxy screw shell T. capensis is much smaller (33 mm), has two spiral ridges running around each whorl and occurs in sheltered sandy from the intertidal downwards. The Threaded screw-shell T. carinifera grows to a larger size (48 mm), has a single spiral ridge running up each whorl and occurs singly among encrusting organisms attached to rocks. The Mottled screw-shell T. sanguinea has rounded whorls with many fine parallel ridges and is marked with reddish-brown streaks. It is much larger, up to 106 mm and buries in sand in deeper areas.

Australian specimens referred to in earlier papers under this name have now been removed to another separate species (T. capiva).
